name: pentostatin
Reason: The compound pentostatin has several functional groups that will influence its melting point: 1) The nucleobase (adenine-like) with N-C-N and ring nitrogen atoms typically stabilizes the structure through hydrogen bonding and pi stacking, which suggests a large increase in melting point. 2) The furanose sugar ring with OH groups is capable of forming hydrogen bonds, which will also increase the melting point. 3) The existence of an extra hydroxyl group on the pentose ring provides additional hydrogen bonding opportunity, further raising the melting point. 4) An amine group will also contribute to hydrogen bonding. The combined effects of the multiple hydrogen bond donors and acceptors and rigid bicyclic structure will significantly elevate the melting point. For quantitative estimation, base structure like adenine might have a melting point in the range of 360; furanose with hydroxyls (+30), extra hydroxyl group on the sugar ring (+10), and an amine group might add another (+20). However, these effects are not simply additive and the actual intermolecular interactions could result in compensatory or synergistic effects, so the predicted increase will be tempered. Therefore, overall, the additional substituents may contribute less to the melting point than the sum of their individual effects, since the basic structure already possesses a high melting point and additional groups contribute to a lesser extent.
